content: The Act is titled the "Private Fund Investment Advisers Registration Act of 2009" and includes definitions for various terms. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to define "private fund" as an issuer exempt from being an investment company under certain sections, and "foreign private fund adviser" as an adviser with no US office, fewer than 15 US clients, and assets under management below a specified amount. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to define a "private fund" as an issuer exempt from being an investment company under certain sections. It also defines a "foreign private fund adviser" as an adviser with no US office, fewer than 15 US clients, and assets under management below a specified amount. The Act also sets criteria for investment advisers exempt from registration requirements in the United States. SEC. 3. ELIMINATION OF PRIVATE ADVISER EXEMPTION; LIMITED EXEMPTION FOR FOREIGN PRIVATE FUND ADVISERS; LIMITED INTRASTATE EXEMPTION. Section 203(b) of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to include exceptions for investment advisers to private funds and foreign private fund advisers. Additionally, the amendment specifies that small business investment companies and entities receiving funding from the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 are exempt from certain requirements. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to exempt certain investment advisers, including those advising small business investment companies licensed under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958, entities receiving funding from the Small Business Administration, and applicants related to licensed small business investment companies. SEC. 4. COLLECTION OF SYSTEMIC RISK DATA. Section 204 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to require investment advisers to maintain records and file reports regarding private funds advised by them for the protection of investors and assessment of systemic risk. The Commission can share this information with the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System and other entities responsible for systemic risk. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to require investment advisers to maintain records and file reports on private funds they advise. This information can be shared with the Federal Reserve and other entities responsible for systemic risk. The reports must include details such as assets under management, leverage, credit risk exposures, trading positions, and other relevant information. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to require investment advisers to maintain records and file reports on private funds they advise. The reports must include details such as assets under management, leverage, credit risk exposures, trading positions, and other relevant information determined necessary by the Commission. Additional information may be required based on the public interest and potential systemic risk. Private fund advisers must maintain records of private funds advised for a specified period as prescribed by the Commission for investor protection and systemic risk assessment. These records are subject to periodic examinations by the Commission or its representatives. Private fund advisers registered under this Act must provide the Commission with copies of records upon request for systemic risk assessment. The Commission shares this information with the Federal Reserve and other entities for assessing the systemic risk of private funds. Private fund advisers registered under this Act must provide reports, records, and documents to investors, counterparties, and creditors as prescribed by the Commission for the public interest, investor protection, and systemic risk assessment. The Commission is not required to disclose any confidential information obtained for this purpose. The Commission is not compelled to disclose any reports or information required to be filed under this subsection, ensuring confidentiality. This provision does not prevent disclosure to Congress, other federal agencies, or courts, as necessary. SEC. 5 eliminates a disclosure provision in the Investment Advisers Act of 1940. SEC. 6 exempts and requires reporting by venture capital fund advisers. SEC. 7 exempts and requires reporting by certain private fund advisers. Section 203 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to provide an exemption from registration requirements for investment advisers of private funds with assets under management in the US of less than $150,000,000. These exempted advisers must maintain records and provide necessary reports to the Commission. Additionally, regulations will be prescribed for mid-sized private fund advisers. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to exempt advisers of private funds with assets under $150,000,000 from registration. Regulations will be prescribed for mid-sized private fund advisers, taking into account their size, governance, and investment strategy to determine systemic risk levels. Registration and examination procedures will reflect the level of systemic risk posed by such funds. SEC. 8. CLARIFICATION OF RULEMAKING AUTHORITY. Section 211 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to grant the Commission authority to make rules and regulations, classify persons and matters based on various criteria, prescribe different requirements for different classes, and assign different meanings to terms. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 is amended to grant the Commission authority to make rules and regulations, classify persons and matters, prescribe different requirements, and assign different meanings to terms. The Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission will jointly establish rules for reports to be filed within 12 months after the enactment of the Private Fund Investment Advisers Registration Act of 2009. The Private Fund Investment Advisers Registration Act of 2009 authorizes the Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to create rules for reports to be filed by investment advisers registered under both the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 and the Commodity Exchange Act. The Private Fund Investment Advisers Registration Act of 2009 authorizes a study by the Comptroller General to assess the costs on industry members and investors due to registration and reporting requirements. A report containing findings and determinations must be submitted to Congress within 2 years of the Act's enactment. Effective date and transition period provisions are also included. SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATE; TRANSITION PERIOD. This Act and its amendments will take effect for investment advisers after a 1-year transition period. The Securities and Exchange Commission will establish rules allowing advisers to register before the deadline. SEC. 11. QUALIFIED CLIENT STANDARD. SEC. 11. QUALIFIED CLIENT STANDARD. The Commission will adjust for inflation every 5 years for any dollar amount test used in making determinations under this subsection. Adjustments not multiples of $1,000 will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $1,000.
